awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 2022 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The 14th International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) 2022 takes place in Paris France from October 24th to October 26th and will bring together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles). The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and, therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention. This award provides travel assistance for ten undergraduate and graduate students to attend this workshop to present research, participate in a computer programming competition, and network with a large community of industrial and academic researchers. These participants will go on to form the foundation of the field in the future.

	Specifically, these students will join a wide variety of researchers (120+) from electronic design automation and synthetic biology in a unique context that does not exist elsewhere. They will have access to between twelve and fifteen technical talks over two days, two invited lectures, ten to twenty posters, multiple group discussion sessions, and a featured student programming competition (BDAthlon). This award covers the registration for the workshop as well as partial support for travel and housing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The 2022 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) convened from October 24th to 26th in Paris, France, hosted at the Learning Planet Institute and the Paris Expo - Porte de Versailles. IWBDA facilitated collaboration between researchers in electronic design automation and synthetic biology, aiming to enhance the engineering of biology for improved reliability and predictability, with implications for advancements in medicine and biology. The event attracted over 100 participants from leading research institutions and industry, with approximately half being graduate students.

Key sponsors, including the NSF and industry leaders such as Asimov, Ganymede, Beckman Coulter, and Lattice Automation, contributed significantly to the workshop's success. The program featured four technical talk sessions covering Biofoundries and Automation, Modeling, Measurement, and Software and Pipelines, with 16 talks selected from peer-reviewed extended abstracts. The abstracts are accessible through the workshop's website.

Additionally, six "mini-workshops" delved into various topics such as Biocircuit Models, Learning Parameters from Experimental Data, and Open Source Software for Biology. Dr. Gregory Batt from Institut Pasteur delivered a keynote address. The event also included 18 poster presentations and engaging group discussions. Notably, ACS Synthetic Biology incorporated submissions into a "special issue" spotlighting the workshop's technical contributions.


For further details, visit http://www.iwbdaconf.org/2022/.


Last Modified: 01/31/2024
Modified by: Douglas Densmore
